newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Some sell calls into divergence.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Some sell calls into divergence.

text.p: A sharp divergence between the Dow industrial average .DJI and S&P 500 futures had some options investors selling calls, but traders said a clear bias to options trading had not emerged.
By 1330 CST/1930 GMT, the Dow was down 55 points, or 0.8 percent, at 6,829. It hit a session low of 6,808.
At the same time, the leading S&P March futures contract was up 1.75 at 788.70, just off its session high of 790.25 which was a record.
Options participants often use the futures in conjunction with index options for various strategies.
"It's a very strange day," one index options broker said. "We're not used to seeing the Dow doing what it's doing and watching the S&Ps doing what they're doing.

"IBM is a tremendous factor in all that," he said, referring to International Business Machines Corp, which was down sharply after reporting quarterly earnings that disappointed some analysts and investors late Tuesday.
IBM shares were off nine at 159 in heavy trading.
"IBM is a major factor in the Dow, but only one stock in the (S&P) 500, so the divergence is normal," one index options trader in Chicago said.
"People are selling calls into the rally," the trader said, adding that some investors were selling call spreads and others were buying vertical put spreads.
A vertical spread is a position made up of a long option at one strike price and a short option at a different strike.
The broker said the divergence of the major indices contributed to a pickup in options index activity in the first few hours of trading but action had slowed after noon.
"It was a very busy morning all over," he said. "People were doing a little of everything."
The market's action led to a slight decline in volatility, with the Chicago Board Options Exchange's volatility index .VIX down about half a point at 18.99.
The index had been holding above the key 20 level since the beginning of January, and closed just below 20 on Tuesday.
At the CBOE, the bias continued to be on the put side, with S&P 100 index .OEX put volume by 1330 CST/1930 GMT topping call volume by 43,376 to 29,775.
Turnover in S&P 500 .SPX index options at the CBOE was relatively heavy and put volume also led call volume. Put volume was 46,127 compared to call volume of 24,351.
In the OEX, the most active option was the February 690 put, which traded about 4,225 contracts. It had open interest of 6,371 through Tuesday
Other busy puts included the February 700, 760 and 765.
With the index trading around 769, the February 760 put was down 1/2 at 11 and the 765 put was down 5/8 at 12-3/4.
Among OEX calls, the February 765 was most active, with volume of about 3,830. Its premium remained rich at 17-5/8.
In the SPX, the most active option was the June 650 put, with volume of about 8,155. The option traded at 4-1/8 and had open interest of 25,344. ((-Gregory Crawford, 312 408 8750))
